urls.title: Your Phone Is a Goldmine of Hidden Data for Cops. Here's How to Fight Back
urls.description: For the thousands of people protesting and reporting on George Floyd’s death at the hands of the Minneapolis Police Department—or even for bystanders caught up in the demonstrations—arrests, injuries, and even death are becoming commonplace in this moment. And just like protests we’ve experienced within the past decade

quotedThread.text:
i wrote this piece 2 years ago when folks were dm'ing me, terrified abt attending protests and leaking sensitive data to cops in the process. this is a loooooong piece (and pretty grim), but most of the same steps apply here. and it's just as grim 

https://t.co/4BPi5QF7Xw

quotedThread.text:
- never bring your phone with you to an abortion clinic. use a burner, if anything (and make sure that burner's off when you're at home)
- never browse any sort of abortion-related content at home, if possible, and never on your own device. go to your local library for that

author_data.description: monetization of our discontents @gizmodo // my signal # is 1-516-668-1794, my wire is @swodinsky, and my email is swodinsky@gizmodo.com
author_data.name: shoshana wodinsky (she/her)

quotedThread.text: - never use your actual email / phone number to sign up for telehealth/clinic consultations. use a new protonmail for each, along with a new voip number. again, try not to do this at home

author_data.description: monetization of our discontents @gizmodo // my signal # is 1-516-668-1794, my wire is @swodinsky, and my email is swodinsky@gizmodo.com
author_data.name: shoshana wodinsky (she/her)

quotedThread.text: - i'm seeing a lot of posts telling folks to delete fertility apps, which frankly, you should (they're notoriously scuzzy). but in my research, i've always found them sharing data about your cycle/pregnancy/birth control, *not* your abortion status https://t.co/JKUswuiBBv

quotedConversation.text: you can use an ad blocker, but tbh the most popular ones are often pawning data, too. if you really, really can't use a burner device, use tor. change your ip address often https://t.co/GekFyRczfS

urls.title: How Your Ad Blocker Can Track You Across the Web
urls.description: A few lines of code hidden away on a webpage can turn your blocked ads into a unique ID.

quotedConversation.text: "social intelligence" is something you should also be aware of. both feds and for-profit brokers use it, and in both cases they're usually looking for keywords related to a given issue (like abortion). if you're gonna tweet about that, use an anon account https://t.co/TY7KbqbzoR

urls.title: Social Media Surveillance by the U.S. Government
urls.description: A growing and unregulated trend of online surveillance raises concerns for civil rights and liberties.

domain.description: Brands and Companies

quotedConversation.text:
calls—to clinics or otherwise—can also be tracked, by "conversation analytics" orgs, which then pawn off metadata from those calls to other brokers

the way you know they're tapped in (usually) is that you'll hear something like "this call is being recorded for quality bla bla"

if you hear that, hang up, walk a few blocks outside, and use your burner to call back. that's admittedly a bit paranoid (this entire thread kinda is), but like..... data privacy in this country is a joke. overkill is the only way through

quotedConversation.text: @robinberjon @kashhill like, i don’t know *who* would sell that kind of audience but it’s totally possible, and could definitely be used for this purpose
@robinberjon @kashhill like, i do know that anti-abortion groups use honeypots / geofences / keyword buys all the time to target folks, but afaik it’s never app data they’re using; it’s like, search

@robinberjon @kashhill i mean it’s not going to be perfect, but in the former example in particular you’d get a *very* good picture of what’s going on. tho wouldn’t they already have that by using keywords alone?

quotedConversation.text: @robinberjon @kashhill i guess it’s a way to filter out false positives, since you have a segment you ostensibly know was pregnant before

gonna amend this thread a bit: if cops get creative enough (like in this example), they could pretty easily use data from fertility apps for persecutions. so yeah, delete those suckers now! https://t.co/dszIiMoctX

@_alialkhatib @robinberjon @kashhill like, stories like these: it’s not about a cop going to an app and subpoenaing, it’s about a middleman seeing an opportunity to cash in, compiling the data to do so, and handing it to the cops. it’s about profit first, arrests after  https://t.co/IWmQqHFUvT

urls.title: Federal Agencies Use Cellphone Location Data for Immigration Enforcement
urls.description: The Trump administration has been using a database that maps the movements of millions of cellphones to monitor the Mexican border and make immigration arrests, according to people familiar with the matter.

urls.title: How Your Ad Blocker Can Track You Across the Web
urls.description: A few lines of code hidden away on a webpage can turn your blocked ads into a unique ID.

quotedConversation.text: you can use an ad blocker, but tbh the most popular ones are often pawning data, too. if you really, really can't use a burner device, use tor. change your ip address often https://t.co/GekFyRczfS

urls.title: Social Media Surveillance by the U.S. Government
urls.description: A growing and unregulated trend of online surveillance raises concerns for civil rights and liberties.

quotedConversation.text: "social intelligence" is something you should also be aware of. both feds and for-profit brokers use it, and in both cases they're usually looking for keywords related to a given issue (like abortion). if you're gonna tweet about that, use an anon account https://t.co/TY7KbqbzoR

domain.name: Brand Category
domain.description: Categories within Brand Verticals that narrow down the scope of Brands

domain.name: Brand
domain.description: Brands and Companies

quotedConversation.text:
calls—to clinics or otherwise—can also be tracked, by "conversation analytics" orgs, which then pawn off metadata from those calls to other brokers

the way you know they're tapped in (usually) is that you'll hear something like "this call is being recorded for quality bla bla"

if you hear that, hang up, walk a few blocks outside, and use your burner to call back. that's admittedly a bit paranoid (this entire thread kinda is), but like..... data privacy in this country is a joke. overkill is the only way through

@robinberjon @kashhill like, i do know that anti-abortion groups use honeypots / geofences / keyword buys all the time to target folks, but afaik it’s never app data they’re using; it’s like, search

@robinberjon @kashhill i mean it’s not going to be perfect, but in the former example in particular you’d get a *very* good picture of what’s going on. tho wouldn’t they already have that by using keywords alone?

quotedConversation.text: @robinberjon @kashhill i guess it’s a way to filter out false positives, since you have a segment you ostensibly know was pregnant before

gonna amend this thread a bit: if cops get creative enough (like in this example), they could pretty easily use data from fertility apps for persecutions. so yeah, delete those suckers now! https://t.co/dszIiMoctX

urls.title: Federal Agencies Use Cellphone Location Data for Immigration Enforcement
urls.description: The Trump administration has been using a database that maps the movements of millions of cellphones to monitor the Mexican border and make immigration arrests, according to people familiar with the matter.

quotedConversation.text: @_alialkhatib @robinberjon @kashhill like, stories like these: it’s not about a cop going to an app and subpoenaing, it’s about a middleman seeing an opportunity to cash in, compiling the data to do so, and handing it to the cops. it’s about profit first, arrests after  https://t.co/IWmQqHFUvT
